Name: Panic disorder
Symptoms: Palpitations, Sweating, Trembling, Shortness of breath, Fear of losing control, Dizziness
Treatment: Treatment typically involves a combination of therapy and medications. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are commonly used.

Name: Vocal cord polyp
Symptoms: Hoarseness, Vocal Changes, Vocal Fatigue
Treatment: Treatment may involve voice therapy, surgical removal of the polyp, or in some cases, voice rest and hydration.

Name: Turner syndrome
Symptoms: Short stature, Gonadal dysgenesis, Webbed neck, Lymphedema
Treatment: Treatment may include growth hormone therapy, estrogen replacement therapy, and addressing associated health issues.

Name: Cryptorchidism
Symptoms: Absence or undescended testicle(s), empty scrotum, smaller or underdeveloped testicle(s), inguinal hernia, abnormal positioning of the testicle(s) (higher in the groin area)
Treatment: Treatment options include hormone therapy, surgical placement of the testicle(s), orchiopexy, or orchiectomy.

Name: Ethylene glycol poisoning-1
Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, General malaise, weakness, Increased thirst, frequent urination
Treatment: Immediate medical treatment is essential. This may include supportive care, administration of antidotes, and monitoring of kidney function.

Name: Ethylene glycol poisoning-2
Symptoms: Metabolic acidosis, apid breathing, rapid heart rate, confusion, headache, dizziness, seizures
Treatment: Emergency treatment is needed. Treatment may involve administration of antidotes, supportive care, and management of acid-base balance.

Name: Ethylene glycol poisoning-3
Symptoms: Decreased urine output, swelling in the legs and ankles, and signs of fluid overload, Severe kidney damage
Treatment: Urgent medical attention is necessary. Treatment focuses on managing kidney damage and supporting kidney function.

Name: Atrophic vaginitis
Symptoms: Vaginal dryness, Vaginal burning, frequent urination, urinary tract infections, Painful intercourse
Treatment: Treatment may include topical estrogen therapy, vaginal moisturizers, and lubricants.

Name: Fracture
Symptoms: Pain, Swelling, Bruising, Deformity, Difficulty moving, Loss of function
Treatment: Treatment depends on the type and severity of the fracture. It may involve immobilization, reduction, surgical intervention, and rehabilitation.

Name: Cellulitis
Symptoms: Redness, Pain, tenderness, Swelling, Skin changes, Lymph node enlargement
Treatment: Treatment typically involves oral or intravenous antibiotics, rest, and elevation of the affected area.

Name: Eye alignment disorder
Symptoms: Double vision, Eye fatigue, Poor depth perception, Head tilting
Treatment: Treatment options include corrective lenses, vision therapy, prism glasses, or in some cases, surgery.

Name: Headache after lumbar puncture
Symptoms: throbbing headache
Treatment: Treatment may involve pain management strategies such as rest, hydration, and over-the-counter pain relievers.

Name: Pyloric stenosis
Symptoms: Persistent hunger, Weight loss, Dehydration, Visible peristalsis, Palpable mass, Fussiness
Treatment: Treatment usually involves surgery (pyloromyotomy) to widen the pyloric channel and alleviate the obstruction.

Name: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
Symptoms: Lump, swelling, Facial numbness, tingling
Treatment: Treatment may include surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy, depending on the extent and location of the tumor.

Name: Pleomorphic adenoma
Symptoms: Painless lump or swelling, Facial changes
Treatment: Surgical removal (excision) is the primary treatment. In some cases, radiation therapy may be recommended.

Name: Warthin tumor
Symptoms: Painless lump or swelling, Facial changes
Treatment: Surgical removal (excision) is usually recommended. In rare cases, observation may be appropriate.

Name: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
Symptoms: Lump, swelling, Difficulty, pain when swallowing and speaking, Facial weakness, Facial paralysis
Treatment: Treatment typically involves surgery, sometimes followed by radiation therapy or chemotherapy, depending on the stage and location of the tumor.

Name: Acinic cell carcinoma
Symptoms: Lump, swelling, Facial changes
Treatment: Treatment usually involves surgical removal of the tumor. Radiation therapy or chemotherapy may be recommended in some cases.

Name: Mucocele
Symptoms: Painless fluid-filled swelling in the oral cavity
Treatment: Surgical removal (excision) is often performed to prevent recurrence and alleviate symptoms.

Name: Osteochondrosis
Symptoms: Joint pain, stiffness, swelling, reduced range of motion
Treatment: Treatment may include rest, physical therapy, pain management, and in some cases, surgery.

Name: Sialolithiasis
Symptoms: Swelling, pain, tenderness, difficulty eating
Treatment: Treatment may involve gland massage, hydration, warm compresses, or in some cases, surgical removal of the stone.

Name: Submandibular stones
Symptoms: Swelling, pain, dry mouth, bad taste
Treatment: Treatment may involve gland massage, hydration, warm compresses, or in some cases, surgical removal of the stone.

Name: Parotid stones
Symptoms: Swelling, pain, dry mouth, bad taste
Treatment: Treatment may involve gland massage, hydration, warm compresses, or in some cases, surgical removal of the stone.

Name: Recurrent salivary stones
Symptoms: Frequent episodes of stone formation
Treatment: Preventive measures may include hydration, good oral hygiene, and dietary modifications. In some cases, surgical intervention may be necessary.

Name: Wharton's duct stones
Symptoms: Swelling, pain, dry mouth, bad taste
Treatment: Treatment may involve gland massage, hydration, warm compresses, or in some cases, surgical removal of the stone.

Name: Mumps
Symptoms: Swollen salivary glands (usually parotid), fever, headache, fatigue
Treatment: Treatment focuses on supportive care, including rest, hydration, pain management, and isolation to prevent the spread of the virus.

Name: Ludwig's angina
Symptoms: Severe swelling of the floor of the mouth, fever, difficulty swallowing, drooling
Treatment: Immediate medical attention is essential. Treatment may involve antibiotics, airway management, and surgical drainage, in severe cases.

Name: Mucocele
Symptoms: Painless swelling, usually on the lower lip or floor of the mouth
Treatment: Surgical removal (excision) is typically performed to prevent recurrence and alleviate symptoms.

Name: Abscess
Symptoms: Swelling, pain, redness, fever, pus formation
Treatment: Treatment usually involves incision and drainage of the abscess, along with antibiotics to prevent infection spread.

Name: Sj√∂gren's syndrome
Symptoms: Dry mouth and eyes, fatigue, joint pain, dry skin
Treatment: Treatment aims to relieve symptoms and prevent complications. This may include artificial tears, saliva substitutes, medications to reduce inflammation, and lifestyle modifications.

Name: Open-Angle Glaucoma
Symptoms: Gradual loss of peripheral vision, tunnel vision
Treatment: Treatment aims to lower intraocular pressure to slow or prevent vision loss. This may include eye drops, oral medications, laser therapy, or surgery.

Name: Angle-Closure Glaucoma
Symptoms: Severe eye pain, headache, blurred vision, halos around lights, nausea and vomiting
Treatment: Emergency treatment is needed to lower intraocular pressure and alleviate symptoms. This may include medications and laser or surgical interventions.

Name: Normal-Tension Glaucoma
Symptoms: Gradual loss of vision, visual field defects
Treatment: Treatment aims to lower intraocular pressure to slow or prevent vision loss. This may include eye drops, oral medications, laser therapy, or surgery.

Name: Congenital Glaucoma
Symptoms: Cloudy or hazy eyes, excessive tearing, sensitivity to light
Treatment: Treatment usually involves surgery to improve drainage of the aqueous humor and lower intraocular pressure.

Name: Secondary Glaucoma
Symptoms: Varies depending on the underlying cause
Treatment: Treatment depends on the underlying condition causing secondary glaucoma and may include medications, laser therapy, or surgery.

Name: Pigmentary Glaucoma
Symptoms: Blurred vision, halos around lights, eye pain
Treatment: Treatment aims to lower intraocular pressure to slow or prevent vision loss. This may include eye drops, oral medications, laser therapy, or surgery.

Name: Exfoliation Glaucoma
Symptoms: Elevated intraocular pressure, visual field loss
Treatment: Treatment aims to lower intraocular pressure to slow or prevent vision loss. This may include eye drops, oral medications, laser therapy, or surgery.

Name: Ocular Hypertension
Symptoms: Elevated intraocular pressure without optic nerve damage
Treatment: Treatment may include close monitoring, lifestyle modifications, and medications to lower intraocular pressure.

Name: Low-Tension Glaucoma
Symptoms: Gradual loss of vision, visual field defects
Treatment: Treatment aims to lower intraocular pressure to slow or prevent vision loss. This may include eye drops, oral medications, laser therapy, or surgery.

Name: Anorexia Nervosa
Symptoms: Extreme weight loss, fear of gaining weight, distorted body image
Treatment: Treatment typically involves a multidisciplinary approach including medical care, nutritional rehabilitation, psychotherapy, and family therapy.

Name: Bulimia Nervosa
Symptoms: Recurrent episodes of binge eating followed by purging behaviors
Treatment: Treatment may include psychotherapy, nutritional counseling, medications, and support groups.

Name: Binge Eating Disorder
Symptoms: Recurrent episodes of binge eating without compensatory behaviors
Treatment: Treatment may involve psychotherapy, nutritional counseling, and support groups.

Name: Avoidant/Restrictive Food Intake Disorder (ARFID)
Symptoms: Avoidance or restriction of certain foods or entire food groups, significant weight loss or failure to gain weight
Treatment: Treatment may include nutritional counseling, exposure therapy, and addressing underlying psychological factors.

Name: Other Specified Feeding or Eating Disorder (OSFED)
Symptoms: Symptoms that do not meet the full criteria for a specific eating disorder
Treatment: Treatment is tailored to individual symptoms and may involve a combination of psychotherapy, nutritional counseling, and medication.

Name: Orthorexia Nervosa
Symptoms: Obsessive focus on "clean" eating, healthy food choices
Treatment: Treatment may involve cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) to challenge rigid beliefs about food and nutrition, along with nutritional counseling.

Name: Pica
Symptoms: Persistent consumption of non-food substances
Treatment: Treatment may involve addressing nutritional deficiencies, behavioral therapy, and monitoring for complications.

Name: Rumination Disorder
Symptoms: Repeated regurgitation and re-chewing of food
Treatment: Treatment may include behavioral therapy, dietary changes, and addressing underlying stress or anxiety.

Name: Transient ischemic attack
Symptoms: Sudden onset of neurological symptoms that resolve within 24 hours
Treatment: Immediate medical attention is crucial. Treatment may involve medications to prevent further strokes, lifestyle changes, and addressing underlying risk factors.

Name: Pyelonephritis
Symptoms: Fever, chills, back or flank pain, frequent urination
Treatment: Treatment usually involves antibiotics, hydration, and pain management. In severe cases, hospitalization and intravenous antibiotics may be necessary.

Name: Rotator Cuff Injury
Symptoms: Shoulder pain, weakness or loss of strength, limited range of motion, shoulder stiffness
Treatment: Treatment may include rest, physical therapy, pain management, and in some cases, surgery to repair the rotator cuff.

Name: Fibromyalgia
Symptoms: Widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, sleep disturbances
Treatment: Treatment often involves a combination of medications, physical therapy, exercise, stress management techniques, and lifestyle modifications.

Name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
Symptoms: Extreme fatigue, cognitive difficulties, unrefreshing sleep
Treatment: Treatment focuses on symptom management and may include medications, cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), graded exercise therapy (GET), and lifestyle adjustments.

Name: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS)
Symptoms: Severe and persistent pain, changes in skin color or temperature, swelling, stiffness
Treatment: Treatment may include medications, physical therapy, occupational therapy, sympathetic nerve blocks, and psychological support.

Name: Myofascial Pain Syndrome
Symptoms: Localized muscle pain, trigger points
Treatment: Treatment may involve physical therapy, massage therapy, trigger point injections, medications, and stress management techniques.

Name: Chronic Migraine
Symptoms: Recurrent, disabling migraines
Treatment: Treatment may include medications for acute relief and prevention, lifestyle modifications, stress management techniques, and alternative therapies such as acupuncture or biofeedback.

Name: Neuropathic Pain
Symptoms: Shooting or burning pain, tingling or numbness
Treatment: Treatment may include medications, physical therapy, nerve blocks, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS), and complementary therapies such as acupuncture or mindfulness meditation.

Name: Gestational Diabetes
Symptoms: High blood sugar levels during pregnancy
Treatment: Treatment typically involves blood sugar monitoring, diet and exercise, and in some cases, insulin therapy to keep blood sugar levels under control.

Name: Pregnancy-Induced Hypertension
Symptoms: High blood pressure during pregnancy
Treatment: Treatment may involve close monitoring, lifestyle changes, and in severe cases, medication to lower blood pressure and prevent complications.

Name: Gestational Hypertension
Symptoms: High blood pressure without proteinuria (preeclampsia)
Treatment: Treatment may involve close monitoring, lifestyle changes, and in some cases, medication to lower blood pressure and prevent complications.

Name: Preeclampsia
Symptoms: High blood pressure, proteinuria, swelling, headaches, visual disturbances
Treatment: Immediate medical attention is necessary. Treatment may involve blood pressure management, medication to prevent seizures (if eclampsia develops), and delivery of the baby if the condition is severe.

Name: Hyperemesis Gravidarum
Symptoms: Severe nausea and vomiting during pregnancy
Treatment: Treatment may include intravenous fluids, medications to alleviate nausea and vomiting, nutritional support, and in severe cases, hospitalization.

Name: Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)
Symptoms: Painful urination, frequent urination, pelvic pain, cloudy urine
Treatment: Treatment usually involves antibiotics to clear the infection. Drinking plenty of water and urinating frequently can also help flush out bacteria.

Name: Anemia
Symptoms: Fatigue, weakness, pale skin, shortness of breath
Treatment: Treatment depends on the underlying cause of anemia and may include iron supplementation, vitamin B12 injections, medications to stimulate red blood cell production, or blood transfusions.

Name: Pregnancy-Related Back Pain
Symptoms: Lower back pain, discomfort in the pelvic area
Treatment: Treatment may include prenatal exercises, physical therapy, massage therapy, proper posture techniques, and support devices such as maternity belts.

Name: Round Ligament Pain
Symptoms: Sharp or aching pain in the lower abdomen or groin
Treatment: Treatment may include rest, gentle stretching exercises, heat or cold therapy, and proper body mechanics.

Name: Placenta Previa
Symptoms: Vaginal bleeding, painless bleeding in the third trimester
Treatment: Treatment depends on the severity of the condition and the stage of pregnancy. It may involve bed rest, close monitoring, and delivery by cesarean section if necessary.

Name: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome
Symptoms: Tingling, numbness, and pain in the hand and fingers
Treatment: Treatment may include wrist splinting, activity modification, physical therapy, corticosteroid injections, and in severe cases, surgery to relieve pressure on the median nerve.

Name: Sciatica
Symptoms: Sharp pain, tingling, or numbness that radiates from the lower back through the hips and down the leg
Treatment: Treatment may include rest, physical therapy, heat or ice therapy, pain medication, corticosteroid injections, and in severe cases, surgery to relieve pressure on the sciatic nerve.

Name: Varicose Veins
Symptoms: Enlarged, swollen veins, often in the legs
Treatment: Treatment options include lifestyle changes, compression stockings, exercise, elevation of the legs, and in severe cases, procedures such as sclerotherapy or vein stripping.

Name: Hemorrhoids
Symptoms: Swollen, itchy, or painful veins in the rectal area
Treatment: Treatment may include over-the-counter remedies, topical treatments, lifestyle modifications, and in severe cases, procedures such as rubber band ligation or surgery.

Name: Gestational Cholestasis
Symptoms: Itchy skin, particularly on the hands and feet
Treatment: Treatment may include medications to relieve itching, monitoring of liver function, and early delivery if necessary to prevent complications for the baby.

Name: Liver Cancer
Symptoms: Abdominal pain, jaundice (yellowing of the skin and eyes), unexplained weight loss, loss of appetite, fatigue, nausea, vomiting
Treatment: Treatment options may include surgery, liver transplant, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, targeted therapy, or a combination of these approaches.

Name: Atelectasis
Symptoms: Difficulty breathing, rapid breathing, chest pain
Treatment: Treatment may involve deep breathing exercises, incentive spirometry, chest physiotherapy, bronchodilators, and in severe cases, mechanical ventilation.

Name: Ectopic Pregnancy
Symptoms: Vaginal bleeding, abdominal pain or cramping, shoulder pain (if the fallopian tube ruptures)
Treatment: Immediate medical attention is necessary. Treatment may involve medication to dissolve the pregnancy tissue, or surgery to remove the ectopic pregnancy.

Name: Choledocholithiasis
Symptoms: Abdominal pain (often in the upper right quadrant), jaundice, dark urine, pale stools, nausea, vomiting, endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) with stone removal, sphincterotomy, Cholecystectomy
Treatment: Treatment depends on the size and location of the stones. It may involve procedures such as ERCP with stone removal, sphincterotomy, or surgical removal of the gallbladder.

Name: Cirrhosis
Symptoms: Fatigue, jaundice, abdominal swelling (ascites), easy bruising and bleeding, confusion, loss of appetite, weight loss
Treatment: Treatment focuses on managing symptoms, preventing complications, and addressing the underlying cause. This may include lifestyle changes, medications, and in severe cases, liver transplantation.

Name: Thoracic Aortic Aneurysm
Symptoms: Chest or back pain, shortness of breath, hoarseness, difficulty swallowing
Treatment: Treatment depends on the size and location of the aneurysm. It may involve medications to lower blood pressure, surveillance imaging, or surgery to repair or replace the weakened portion of the aorta.

Name: Subdural hemorrhage
Symptoms: Headache, confusion, dizziness, nausea or vomiting, seizures, weakness or numbness
Treatment: Treatment may involve close monitoring, medications to reduce brain swelling, surgery to drain the hematoma, and rehabilitation to address any neurological deficits.

Name: Congenital rubella
Symptoms: Developmental delays, intellectual disability, hearing loss, vision problems, heart defects, liver or spleen enlargement, rash at birth
Treatment: Treatment focuses on managing symptoms and complications. This may include early intervention programs, special education, hearing aids, vision correction, and treatment of associated health issues.

Name: Diabetic retinopathy
Symptoms: Blurred or distorted vision, floaters, impaired color vision, dark or empty areas in the visual field, vision loss
Treatment: Treatment may involve laser therapy, injections of medications into the eye, vitrectomy surgery, and management of underlying diabetes and other risk factors.

Name: Fibromyalgia
Symptoms: Widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, sleep disturbances, cognitive difficulties (fibro fog), mood changes
Treatment: Treatment often involves a combination of medications, exercise, stress management techniques, and lifestyle modifications to improve symptoms and quality of life.

Name: Ischemia of the Bowel
Symptoms: Severe abdominal pain, bloody stools, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, fever, rapid heart rate, low blood pressure
Treatment: Immediate medical attention is crucial. Treatment may involve surgery to restore blood flow to the affected area of the bowel, antibiotics, and supportive care.

Name: Fetal Alcohol Syndrome
Symptoms: Growth deficiencies, facial abnormalities, developmental delays, intellectual disability
Treatment: Treatment focuses on managing symptoms and providing supportive care. This may include early intervention programs, educational support, behavioral therapy, and addressing associated health issues.

Name: Peritonitis
Symptoms: Severe abdominal pain, tenderness, bloating, fever, nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, increased heart rate
Treatment: Treatment usually involves antibiotics to control the infection, supportive care, and surgery to remove infected tissue or repair perforations.

Name: Abdominal Injury
Symptoms: Abdominal pain, tenderness, bruising, swelling, difficulty breathing, nausea, vomiting, changes in bowel movements, blood in urine or stool
Treatment: Treatment depends on the nature and severity of the injury. It may involve pain management, fluid resuscitation, surgery to repair internal damage, and monitoring for complications.

Name: Acute Pancreatitis
Symptoms: Severe upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, rapid pulse, swollen and tender abdomen, jaundice
Treatment: Treatment may include supportive care, pain management, fasting to rest the pancreas, intravenous fluids, and in severe cases, hospitalization and intensive care.

Name: Thrombophlebitis
Symptoms: Redness, warmth, swelling, and tenderness along a vein, pain or discomfort, skin discoloration, visible veins, fever
Treatment: Treatment may involve anti-inflammatory medications, compression therapy, elevation of the affected limb, and in some cases, blood thinners.

Name: Asthma
Symptoms: Recurrent episodes of wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, coughing, especially at night or in response to triggers such as allergens or exercise
Treatment: Treatment usually involves medications to control inflammation and bronchodilators to relieve symptoms. Avoiding triggers and having a written asthma action plan are also important.

Name: Restless Leg Syndrome
Symptoms: Uncomfortable sensation in the legs, usually in the evening or at night, urge to move legs for relief
Treatment: Treatment options include lifestyle changes, medications to alleviate symptoms, iron supplementation (if iron deficiency is present), and addressing underlying conditions.

Name: Emphysema
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, wheezing, chronic cough, chest tightness, fatigue, weight loss
Treatment: Treatment focuses on symptom management and may include medications, pulmonary rehabilitation, supplemental oxygen therapy, and lifestyle changes such as smoking cessation.

Name: Induced Abortion
Symptoms: Vaginal bleeding, cramping, abdominal pain, nausea, fatigue, emotional distress
Treatment: Treatment may involve counseling, support, and access to medical care as needed.

Name: Acute Sinusitis
Symptoms: Facial pain or pressure, nasal congestion, thick nasal discharge, post-nasal drip, cough, headache, fatigue, fever (in some cases)
Treatment: Treatment may include supportive care, such as rest and hydration, along with medications to relieve symptoms, such as decongestants, antihistamines, nasal corticosteroids, and pain relievers.

Name: Von Hippel-Lindau Disease
Symptoms: Hemangioblastomas (tumors in the brain, spinal cord, or other organs), retinal angiomas (abnormal blood vessel growth in the retina), renal cell carcinomas (kidney tumors), pheochromocytomas (adrenal gland tumors), pancreatic cysts/tumors, other tumors or cysts
Treatment: Treatment depends on the location and extent of tumors or cysts. It may involve surveillance, surgical removal, radiation therapy, or other targeted treatments.

Name: Alcohol Use Disorder
Symptoms: Cravings for alcohol, inability to control or limit alcohol consumption, withdrawal symptoms (such as tremors, anxiety, sweating) when attempting to stop or reduce alcohol use, continued use despite negative consequences (such as relationship problems, health issues), neglecting responsibilities, tolerance to alcohol
Treatment: Treatment may involve detoxification, counseling, support groups (such as Alcoholics Anonymous), medications to reduce cravings or block the effects of alcohol, and addressing underlying mental health issues.

Name: Opioid Use Disorder
Symptoms: Compulsive use of opioids, strong desire or cravings for opioids, inability to control or reduce opioid use, withdrawal symptoms (such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle pain) when attempting to stop or cut back, continued use despite negative consequences (such as legal problems, relationship issues), tolerance to opioids
Treatment: Treatment may involve medication-assisted treatment (such as methadone or buprenorphine), counseling, support groups (such as Narcotics Anonymous), and addressing underlying mental health issues.

Name: Postpartum Depression
Symptoms: Persistent feelings of sadness, hopelessness, irritability, anxiety, fatigue, changes in appetite or sleep, difficulty bonding with the baby, thoughts of self-harm or harming the baby
Treatment: Treatment may include therapy, support groups, medications (such as antidepressants), lifestyle changes, and assistance with childcare.

Name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
Symptoms: Joint hypermobility, joint instability, skin hyperextensibility, tissue fragility, easy bruising, chronic pain, fatigue, gastrointestinal issues, cardiovascular problems
Treatment: Treatment focuses on managing symptoms and preventing complications. This may include physical therapy, pain management, bracing or splinting, surgery, and lifestyle modifications.

Name: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura
Symptoms: Easy or excessive bruising, petechiae (small red or purple spots on the skin), bleeding from the gums or nose, prolonged bleeding from minor cuts or injuries
Treatment: Treatment may involve medications to increase platelet production or prevent the destruction of platelets, and in some cases, removal of the spleen (splenectomy).

Name: Stimulant Use Disorder
Symptoms: Increased energy and alertness, euphoria, decreased appetite, increased heart rate and blood pressure, insomnia, restlessness, irritability, paranoia, psychosis (in severe cases)
Treatment: Treatment may involve therapy, support groups, counseling, and in some cases, medication to manage withdrawal symptoms and cravings.

Name: Cannabis Use Disorder or substance use disorder
Symptoms: Increased appetite, relaxation, altered perception of time, impaired memory and concentration, bloodshot eyes, anxiety or paranoia (in some individuals), withdrawal symptoms (such as irritability, insomnia) when attempting to stop or reduce cannabis use, continued use despite negative consequences (such as relationship problems, job difficulties)
Treatment: Treatment may involve therapy, support groups, counseling, and in some cases, medication to manage withdrawal symptoms and cravings.

Name: Benzodiazepine Use Disorder
Symptoms: Sedation, relaxation, reduced anxiety, drowsiness, poor coordination, memory impairment, withdrawal symptoms (such as rebound anxiety, insomnia, tremors) when attempting to stop or reduce benzodiazepine use, continued use despite negative consequences (such as relationship problems, health risks)
Treatment: Treatment may involve therapy, support groups, counseling, and in some cases, medication to manage withdrawal symptoms and cravings.

Name: Hallucinogen Use Disorder
Symptoms: Altered perception of reality, visual or auditory hallucinations, changes in sensory experiences, introspective thoughts, feelings of connection or disconnection, anxiety or paranoia (in some individuals), flashbacks (in some individuals)
Treatment: Treatment may involve therapy, support groups, counseling, and in some cases, medication to manage withdrawal symptoms and cravings.

Name: Sedative Use Disorder
Symptoms: Sedation, relaxation, reduced anxiety, drowsiness, poor coordination, memory impairment, withdrawal symptoms (such as rebound anxiety, insomnia, tremors) when attempting to stop or reduce use, continued use despite negative consequences (such as relationship problems, health risks)
Treatment: Treatment may involve therapy, support groups, counseling, and in some cases, medication to manage withdrawal symptoms and cravings.

Name: Postpartum Depression
Symptoms: Persistent feelings of sadness, emptiness, or hopelessness, frequent crying, irritability, loss of interest or pleasure in activities, difficulty bonding with the baby, changes in appetite or sleep patterns, overwhelming fatigue, feelings of guilt or worthlessness, trouble concentrating or making decisions, thoughts of self-harm or harming the baby
Treatment: Treatment may include therapy, support groups, medications (such as antidepressants), lifestyle changes, and assistance with childcare.

Name: Coronary Atherosclerosis
Symptoms: Chest pain or discomfort (angina), shortness of breath, fatigue, irregular heartbeat, dizziness, nausea, sweating, jaw or arm pain (in some cases), heart attack (when a coronary artery becomes completely blocked)
Treatment: Treatment may involve lifestyle changes (such as diet and exercise), medications (such as statins, blood thinners), and procedures (such as angioplasty or bypass surgery) to improve blood flow to the heart.

Name: Spondylitis
Symptoms: Chronic back pain and stiffness, especially in the morning or after periods of inactivity, limited range of motion in the spine, fatigue, inflammation and pain in other joints (such as hips, shoulders, knees), discomfort or pain in the neck, difficulty maintaining proper posture, tenderness or swelling in affected areas, tingling or numbness in extremities in severe cases
Treatment: Treatment may include medication to reduce inflammation and pain, physical therapy, exercise, and in some cases, surgery to correct spinal deformities or relieve pressure on nerves.

Name: Pituitary Adenoma
Symptoms: Headaches, vision problems (such as blurred vision or loss of peripheral vision), hormonal imbalances (such as excessive production or deficiency of specific hormones), fatigue, weight gain or loss, menstrual irregularities, infertility, erectile dysfunction, growth abnormalities in children, mood changes, cognitive impairments
Treatment: Treatment depends on the size and location of the tumor, as well as its hormonal activity. Options may include medication to control hormone levels, surgery to remove the tumor, radiation therapy, or a combination of these approaches.

Name: Uterine Fibroids
Symptoms: Heavy or prolonged menstrual periods, pelvic pain or pressure, frequent urination, difficulty emptying the bladder, constipation, backache, leg pain, enlarged abdomen or uterus, infertility or recurrent miscarriages (in some cases)
Treatment: Treatment options may include medication to relieve symptoms, hormone therapy, minimally invasive procedures (such as uterine artery embolization or focused ultrasound surgery), or surgery (such as myomectomy or hysterectomy) to remove the fibroids.

Name: Idiopathic Nonmenstrual Bleeding
Symptoms: Abnormal vaginal bleeding outside of the menstrual period, unpredictable bleeding episodes, bleeding after sexual intercourse, bleeding after menopause, spotting or light bleeding between periods, prolonged or heavy bleeding
Treatment: Treatment depends on the underlying cause and severity of the bleeding. Options may include hormonal therapy, medication to control bleeding, or procedures to address any underlying conditions (such as endometrial ablation or surgery).

Name: Chalazion
Symptoms: Painful, red lump or swelling on the eyelid, usually on the upper eyelid, sensitivity to light, blurred vision (if the chalazion affects the line of sight), mild discomfort, tenderness, localized inflammation and swelling
Treatment: Treatment may involve warm compresses, gentle massage, and eyelid hygiene to promote drainage of the blocked gland. In some cases, steroid injections or surgical removal of the chalazion may be necessary.

Name: Ovarian Torsion
Symptoms: Sudden and severe abdominal or pelvic pain on one side, sharp or stabbing pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, rapid heartbeat, abdominal tenderness, bloating, swelling, pain during intercourse, abnormal bleeding or spotting
Treatment: Immediate medical attention is necessary. Treatment may involve surgery to untwist the ovary and restore blood flow, along with removal of any cysts or masses that contributed to the torsion.

Name: Vaginal Yeast Infection
Symptoms: Itching and irritation in the vagina and vulva, redness and swelling of the vulva, white, thick, clumpy vaginal discharge (resembling cottage cheese), burning sensation during urination, pain during sexual intercourse, rash or soreness in the affected area
Treatment: Treatment typically involves antifungal medication, such as topical creams, ointments, or suppositories, as well as oral antifungal medication in some cases. It's also important to address any underlying factors that may contribute to recurrent yeast infections.

Name: Mastoiditis
Symptoms: Ear pain (particularly behind the ear), swelling and redness of the ear or the area behind the ear, fever, headache, hearing loss or impaired hearing, drainage of fluid or pus from the ear, earache, irritability (in infants and young children), tenderness or pain when touching the area, mastoid bone protrusion or swelling
Treatment: Treatment usually involves antibiotics to clear the infection, along with pain relievers to manage discomfort. In some cases, surgical drainage of the mastoid bone may be necessary.

Name: Lung Contusion
Symptoms: Chest pain (sharp or dull), difficulty breathing or shortness of breath, rapid or shallow breathing, coughing up blood or pink-tinged sputum, decreased oxygen levels, wheezing, cyanosis (bluish discoloration of the skin), chest wall bruising, rib fractures (associated injuries)
Treatment: Treatment focuses on supportive care to manage symptoms and promote healing. This may include pain medication, supplemental oxygen therapy, respiratory support (such as mechanical ventilation), and monitoring for complications (such as pneumonia or respiratory failure).

Name: Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM)
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, especially during physical activity or exertion, chest pain or discomfort, dizziness or lightheadedness, fainting or near-fainting episodes, heart palpitations (rapid or irregular heartbeat), fatigue, swelling in the ankles, feet, or legs
Treatment: Treatment aims to relieve symptoms, prevent complications, and reduce the risk of sudden cardiac death. Options may include medications (such as beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, or antiarrhythmic drugs), surgical procedures (such as septal myectomy or alcohol septal ablation), and implantation of a pacemaker or defibrillator.

Name: Pulmonary Eosinophilia
Symptoms: Cough, shortness of breath, wheezing, chest pain, fever, night sweats, fatigue, weight loss, elevated eosinophil count in the blood or sputum
Treatment: Treatment depends on the underlying cause. Options may include medications to reduce inflammation (such as corticosteroids), antibiotics or antiparasitic drugs if an infection is present, and avoidance of triggers (such as allergens or certain medications).

Name: Corneal Disorder
Symptoms: Blurred or hazy vision, eye pain or discomfort, redness or irritation of the eye, excessive tearing, sensitivity to light (photophobia), foreign body sensation, dryness or excessive tearing, corneal abrasions or ulcers, distorted or irregular corneal shape, vision loss
Treatment: Treatment depends on the specific disorder and may include lubricating eye drops, antibiotics or antiviral medication for infections, corticosteroid eye drops to reduce inflammation, and in severe cases, surgical procedures such as corneal transplantation.

Name: Foreign Body in the Gastrointestinal Tract
Symptoms: Abdominal pain or discomfort, difficulty swallowing, choking or gagging, drooling, nausea or vomiting, loss of appetite, chest pain or pressure, respiratory distress, coughing or wheezing, gastrointestinal bleeding, bowel obstruction, perforation of the digestive tract
Treatment: Treatment depends on the location and nature of the foreign body. In some cases, it may pass through the digestive tract naturally. Other options include endoscopic removal, surgical intervention, or supportive care to manage complications such as infection or obstruction.

Name: Endophthalmitis
Symptoms: Eye pain, redness, swelling, blurred vision, decreased vision, floaters (dark spots or cobwebs in the vision), increased sensitivity to light (photophobia), discharge from the eye, excessive tearing, fever
Treatment: Treatment typically involves urgent administration of intravitreal antibiotics or antifungal medications, along with systemic antibiotics or antifungals. In severe cases, surgical intervention such as vitrectomy may be necessary to remove infected tissue and preserve vision.

Name: Achalasia
Symptoms: Difficulty swallowing
Treatment: Treatment may include lifestyle modifications (such as eating smaller, more frequent meals), dietary changes (such as avoiding foods that trigger symptoms), medication to relax the lower esophageal sphincter, pneumatic dilation (stretching) of the esophagus, botulinum toxin injection, or surgical procedures (such as laparoscopic Heller myotomy) to improve esophageal function.

Name: Conductive Hearing Loss
Symptoms: Reduced hearing sensitivity, muffled or blocked sound
Treatment: Treatment depends on the underlying cause of the hearing loss. Options may include medical management (such as treatment of ear infections or removal of earwax), hearing aids or assistive devices, and in some cases, surgical procedures (such as tympanoplasty or stapedectomy) to repair damaged structures in the middle ear.

Name: Abdominal Hernia
Symptoms: Visible bulge or swelling, discomfort or pain
Treatment: Treatment typically involves surgery to repair the hernia and prevent complications such as incarceration or strangulation. In some cases, especially with small or asymptomatic hernias, watchful waiting may be appropriate.

Name: Marijuana Abuse
Symptoms: Impaired memory and cognition, altered judgment, anxiety
Treatment: Treatment may involve therapy, support groups, counseling, and in some cases, medication to manage withdrawal symptoms and cravings.

Name: Cryptococcosis
Symptoms: Headache, fever, fatigue, cough, meningitis, pneumonia
Treatment: Treatment depends on the severity and location of the infection. Options may include antifungal medications (such as amphotericin B or fluconazole), along with supportive care to manage symptoms and complications.

Name: Obesity
Symptoms: Excessive body weight, increased risk of chronic conditions
Treatment: Treatment may involve lifestyle modifications (such as diet and exercise), behavioral therapy, medications (such as appetite suppressants or drugs that reduce fat absorption), and in some cases, bariatric surgery.

Name: Indigestion
Symptoms: Abdominal pain, bloating, heartburn, nausea, acidic taste
Treatment: Treatment may involve lifestyle changes (such as dietary modifications and stress reduction), medications (such as antacids, H2 blockers, or proton pump inhibitors), and in some cases, treatment of underlying conditions that contribute to indigestion.

Name: Bursitis
Symptoms: Joint pain, swelling, tenderness, limited range of motion
Treatment: Treatment may include rest, ice, compression, and elevation (RICE therapy), along with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), physical therapy, corticosteroid injections, and in some cases, aspiration of excess fluid from the bursa.

Name: Esophageal Cancer
Symptoms: Difficulty swallowing, unintentional weight loss, chest pain, hoarseness
Treatment: Treatment depends on the stage and location of the cancer. Options may include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, targeted therapy, and immunotherapy, as well as palliative care to manage symptoms and improve quality of life.

Name: Pulmonary Congestion
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, cough, wheezing, fatigue, chest discomfort or tightness
Treatment: Treatment focuses on addressing the underlying cause, such as heart failure or lung disease. Options may include diuretics (to reduce fluid buildup), oxygen therapy, medications (such as bronchodilators or corticosteroids), and lifestyle modifications (such as quitting smoking and avoiding triggers).

Name: Juvenile Rheumatoid Arthritis
Symptoms: Joint pain, swelling, stiffness, limited range of motion, fever, rash
Treatment: Treatment may involve medications (such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs, or biologic agents), physical therapy, occupational therapy, and in some cases, lifestyle modifications (such as exercise and healthy diet).

Name: Actinic Keratosis
Symptoms: Rough, scaly patches on the skin, usually in sun-exposed areas
Treatment: Treatment may involve topical medications (such as imiquimod or fluorouracil cream), cryotherapy (freezing), curettage (scraping), photodynamic therapy, or laser therapy, along with sun protection and regular skin exams to monitor for skin cancer.

Name: Acute Otitis Media
Symptoms: Ear pain, fever, fluid drainage from the ear, hearing loss or muffled hearing in the affected ear
Treatment: Treatment may involve watchful waiting (especially in mild cases), pain management with over-the-counter medications, antibiotics (if bacterial infection is suspected or confirmed), and in some cases, placement of ear tubes to prevent recurrent infections.

Name: Astigmatism
Symptoms: Blurred or distorted vision, eye strain, headaches
Treatment: Treatment typically involves corrective lenses (eyeglasses or contact lenses) to compensate for the irregular shape of the cornea or lens. In some cases, refractive surgery (such as LASIK) may be recommended to reshape the cornea and improve vision.

Name: Tuberous Sclerosis
Symptoms: Benign tumors in various organs, seizures, developmental delays, skin abnormalities
Treatment: Treatment aims to manage symptoms and complications associated with the disorder. Options may include antiepileptic medications to control seizures, behavioral interventions, surgery to remove tumors or repair organ damage, and supportive therapies (such as physical therapy or speech therapy).

Name: Empyema
Symptoms: Fever, chest pain, productive cough with foul-smelling or bloody sputum
Treatment: Treatment typically involves antibiotics to clear the infection, along with drainage of the infected fluid from the pleural space. In some cases, surgery may be necessary to remove thickened, infected tissue or to repair any underlying lung or chest wall damage.

Name: Presbycusis
Symptoms: Gradual hearing loss, difficulty hearing high-pitched sounds, speech sounds muffled or unclear
Treatment: Treatment may include hearing aids or assistive devices to amplify sounds and improve communication, auditory rehabilitation programs to develop coping strategies, and lifestyle modifications (such as avoiding loud noise and protecting the ears).

Name: Neonatal Jaundice
Symptoms: Yellowing of the skin and eyes, pale stools, dark urine
Treatment: Treatment may involve phototherapy (exposure to special lights that help break down bilirubin), exchange transfusion (to replace the baby's blood with donor blood), or intravenous immunoglobulin therapy (to reduce bilirubin levels). In some cases, underlying conditions that contribute to jaundice may require additional treatment.

Name: Dislocation of the Elbow
Symptoms: Severe pain, visible deformity, swelling, inability to move the elbow, numbness or tingling in the hand/arm
Treatment: Immediate medical attention is necessary. Treatment typically involves gentle manipulation to relocate the dislocated elbow, followed by immobilization with a splint or sling and rehabilitation exercises to restore strength and range of motion.

Name: Spondylosis
Symptoms: Neck or back pain, stiffness, limited range of motion, numbness or weakness in the extremities
Treatment: Treatment may include rest, physical therapy, stretching and strengthening exercises, pain management with medications (such as NSAIDs or muscle relaxants), and in some cases, injections (such as corticosteroids or nerve blocks) to reduce inflammation and relieve pain.

Name: Herpangina
Symptoms: Sore throat, fever, painful sores or blisters in the mouth and throat, difficulty swallowing, loss of appetite
Treatment: Treatment typically focuses on relieving symptoms and preventing dehydration. Options may include pain relievers (such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen), cold fluids or popsicles to soothe the throat, and maintaining adequate hydration with water or oral rehydration solutions.

Name: Poisoning due to Antidepressants
Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, drowsiness, dizziness, confusion, seizures, changes in heart rate, low blood pressure, respiratory distress
Treatment: Treatment may involve supportive care to stabilize vital signs and manage symptoms. Depending on the specific antidepressant involved, additional interventions such as activated charcoal administration, gastric lavage (stomach pumping), or antidotes (such as physostigmine for tricyclic antidepressant poisoning) may be necessary.

Name: Infection of Open Wound
Symptoms: Redness, swelling, warmth, pain or tenderness at the wound site, pus or drainage from the wound, fever, malaise
Treatment: Treatment typically involves cleaning and dressing the wound, along with antibiotics to prevent or treat infection. In some cases, surgical debridement (removal of dead tissue) or closure may be necessary.

Name: Protein Deficiency
Symptoms: Muscle wasting, fatigue, weakness, delayed wound healing, swelling of the limbs, hair loss, impaired immunity
Treatment: Treatment involves increasing protein intake through dietary changes and, in some cases, supplementation. Addressing the underlying cause of the deficiency (such as malnutrition or gastrointestinal disorders) is also important.

Name: Myoclonus
Symptoms: Sudden, brief muscle contractions or jerks, often affecting the arms, legs, or face
Treatment: Treatment depends on the underlying cause and severity of myoclonus. Options may include medications (such as antiepileptic drugs, benzodiazepines, or muscle relaxants), physical therapy, and lifestyle modifications (such as avoiding triggers or managing stress).

Name: Bone Spur of the Calcaneus
Symptoms: Heel pain, especially when walking or standing, tenderness, swelling, inflammation of the surrounding tissue
Treatment: Treatment may include rest, ice, stretching exercises, orthotic devices (such as heel pads or shoe inserts), pain relievers (such as NSAIDs), physical therapy, and in severe cases, corticosteroid injections or surgery to remove the bone spur.

Name: Von Willebrand Disease
Symptoms: Easy or excessive bruising, prolonged or excessive bleeding from cuts or injuries, frequent nosebleeds, heavy or prolonged menstrual periods, bleeding gums, blood in urine or stool
Treatment: Treatment depends on the severity of the disease and may include medications (such as desmopressin or clotting factor concentrates), blood transfusions, and measures to control bleeding during procedures or surgeries. Avoiding medications that affect platelet function is also important.

Name: Heart Block
Symptoms: Fatigue, dizziness, fainting, chest pain or discomfort, shortness of breath, irregular heart rhythms
Treatment: Treatment depends on the type and severity of heart block. Options may include medications (such as beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers), pacemaker implantation to regulate heart rhythm, and lifestyle modifications (such as avoiding triggers and managing underlying conditions).

Name: Colonic Polyp
Symptoms: Most colonic polyps do not cause symptoms. Some larger polyps or certain types may cause rectal bleeding or changes in bowel habits, such as diarrhea or constipation.
Treatment: Treatment typically involves removal of the polyp during colonoscopy, along with surveillance colonoscopies to monitor for recurrence or development of additional polyps. In some cases, surgery may be necessary, especially for large or cancerous polyps.

Name: Hypospadias
Symptoms: Abnormal positioning of the urethral opening on the underside of the penis, penile curvature, spraying of urine, difficulty in urination
Treatment: Treatment usually involves surgery to correct the position of the urethral opening and improve urinary function. The specific procedure depends on the severity and location of the hypospadias.

Name: Magnesium Deficiency
Symptoms: Muscle twitches or cramps, fatigue, weakness, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, irritability, mental confusion, irregular heartbeat, tingling or numbness, personality changes, seizures
Treatment: Treatment typically involves magnesium supplementation, either through dietary changes or oral supplements. In severe cases or when oral intake is not possible, magnesium may be administered intravenously under medical supervision.

Name: Female Infertility of Unknown Cause
Symptoms: Inability to conceive after one year of unprotected intercourse, irregular or absent menstrual cycles, hormonal imbalances, age-related factors, other
Treatment: Treatment depends on the underlying cause of infertility and may include medications to induce ovulation, hormonal therapy, surgery to correct structural issues, assisted reproductive techniques (such as in vitro fertilization or intrauterine insemination), and lifestyle modifications (such as weight loss or smoking cessation).

Name: Pericarditis
Symptoms: Chest pain (sharp and stabbing), worsens with deep breaths or lying down, fever
Treatment: Treatment may include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to reduce inflammation and relieve pain, along with colchicine to prevent recurrence in some cases. In severe or complicated cases, corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive medications may be necessary. Antibiotics are not effective for viral pericarditis but may be used if bacterial infection is suspected.

Name: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)
Symptoms: Inattention, hyperactivity, impulsivity
Treatment: Treatment typically involves a combination of behavioral therapy, parent education, and medications (such as stimulants, nonstimulants, or antidepressants) to manage symptoms and improve functioning. Individualized treatment plans may also address any coexisting conditions (such as anxiety or learning disabilities).

Name: Lyme Disease
Symptoms: Early symptoms may include fever, chills, headache, fatigue, muscle and joint aches, swollen lymph nodes, erythema migrans (bull's-eye rash). Later symptoms may involve severe headaches, neck stiffness, facial palsy, arthritis with severe joint pain and swelling, heart palpitations, dizziness, shortness of breath, nerve pain, shooting pains, numbness or tingling in the hands or feet, problems with short-term memory.
Treatment: Treatment involves antibiotics, such as doxycycline, amoxicillin, or cefuroxime axetil, depending on the stage of the disease and the patient's age and medical history. In some cases, especially if symptoms persist or complications develop, prolonged antibiotic therapy or intravenous antibiotics may be necessary.

Name: Skin Cancer
Symptoms: Changes in the skin, such as a new growth, a sore that doesn't heal, or a change in a mole, may indicate skin cancer. Basal cell carcinoma may appear as a shiny, pearly bump or as a pinkish patch of skin. Squamous cell carcinoma may appear as a firm, red nodule or as a rough, scaly area. Melanoma may manifest as a mole or skin lesion with irregular borders, asymmetry, uneven coloration, or changes in size or shape.
Treatment: Treatment depends on the type, stage, and location of the skin cancer. Options may include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, immunotherapy, targeted therapy, and Mohs surgery for certain types of skin cancer.

Name: Pancreatitis
Symptoms: Upper abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, fever, rapid pulse, swollen or tender abdomen, decreased appetite
Treatment: Treatment may involve hospitalization for supportive care, including intravenous fluids, pain relief, and management of complications such as infection. In severe cases, surgery may be necessary to remove damaged tissue or treat complications such as pseudocysts or infected necrosis.

Name: Cystic Fibrosis
Symptoms: Persistent cough with thick mucus, frequent lung infections (such as pneumonia or bronchitis), wheezing, shortness of breath, poor growth or weight gain despite a good appetite, salty-tasting skin, chronic sinusitis or nasal polyps, greasy or bulky stools, difficulty with bowel movements
Treatment: Treatment aims to manage symptoms, prevent complications, and improve quality of life. Options may include airway clearance techniques, medications (such as bronchodilators, antibiotics, mucolytics, or CFTR modulators), nutritional support, exercise, and in some cases, lung transplantation.

Name: Premature Ovarian Failure
Symptoms: Irregular or absent menstrual periods, hot flashes, night sweats, vaginal dryness, decreased sex drive, irritability or difficulty concentrating, infertility
Treatment: Treatment focuses on managing symptoms and addressing any underlying causes or contributing factors. Options may include hormone replacement therapy (HRT) to alleviate symptoms of estrogen deficiency, fertility treatments (such as in vitro fertilization with donor eggs), counseling and support, and lifestyle modifications (such as healthy diet and exercise).

Name: Diverticulitis
Symptoms: Abdominal pain (usually in the lower left side), fever, nausea, vomiting, constipation or diarrhea, bloating, changes in bowel habits, rectal bleeding
Treatment: Treatment may involve antibiotics to clear the infection, along with dietary modifications (such as a clear liquid or low-fiber diet during acute episodes) and pain management. In some cases, hospitalization and intravenous antibiotics may be necessary, especially if complications such as abscess or perforation occur.

Name: Cryptosporidiosis
Symptoms: Watery diarrhea, stomach cramps or pain, stomach cramps, stomach ache, fever, nausea, vomiting, dehydration, weight loss
Treatment: Treatment typically involves supportive care to manage symptoms and prevent dehydration, such as oral rehydration solutions and, in severe cases, intravenous fluids. Antiparasitic medications may be prescribed for immunocompromised individuals or those with severe symptoms, but they may not be effective in all cases.

Name: Gout
Symptoms: Sudden, severe joint pain (usually in the big toe), swelling, redness, warmth, stiffness, limited range of motion, lingering discomfort after the acute phase resolves
Treatment: Treatment aims to relieve pain, reduce inflammation, and prevent future gout attacks. Options may include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), colchicine, corticosteroids, and medications to lower uric acid levels (such as allopurinol or febuxostat). Lifestyle modifications (such as dietary changes and weight loss) may also be recommended to manage risk factors.

Name: Gingivitis
Symptoms: Swollen, tender, or bleeding gums, receding gums, persistent bad breath, changes in the way teeth fit together when biting, loose teeth
Treatment: Treatment typically involves professional dental cleaning (scaling and root planing) to remove plaque and tartar buildup, along with proper oral hygiene practices at home (such as brushing, flossing, and using antimicrobial mouthwash). In some cases, additional treatments such as antibiotics or antiseptic mouth rinses may be recommended.

Name: Acne
Symptoms: Pimples, blackheads, whiteheads, cysts, nodules, oily skin, redness, inflammation
Treatment: Treatment may include topical medications (such as retinoids, benzoyl peroxide, or antibiotics), oral medications (such as antibiotics, hormonal therapy, or isotretinoin), and in-office procedures (such as chemical peels, light therapy, or extraction of comedones). Personalized treatment plans often involve a combination of approaches tailored to the individual's specific type and severity of acne.

Name: Neuromyelitis Optica
Symptoms: Optic neuritis (vision loss, pain with eye movement), transverse myelitis (weakness, numbness, or paralysis of the limbs, loss of bladder or bowel control)
Treatment: Treatment for Neuromyelitis Optica typically involves immunosuppressive medications to reduce inflammation and prevent relapses. High-dose corticosteroids may be used to manage acute attacks, followed by long-term treatment with medications such as azathioprine, rituximab, or mycophenolate mofetil to prevent future episodes. Plasma exchange therapy may be considered for severe cases. Physical therapy, occupational therapy, and lifestyle modifications may also be recommended to manage symptoms and improve quality of life.

Name: Pulmonic Valve Disease
Symptoms: Fatigue, shortness of breath, chest pain or discomfort, heart palpitations, fainting or lightheadedness, swollen legs or ankles
Treatment: Treatment for Pulmonic Valve Disease depends on the severity of symptoms and the underlying cause. Options may include medications to manage symptoms (such as diuretics, beta-blockers, or calcium channel blockers), surgery to repair or replace the valve, or minimally invasive procedures (such as balloon valvuloplasty) to improve valve function. Lifestyle modifications (such as quitting smoking, maintaining a healthy weight, and regular exercise) may also be recommended to manage risk factors and improve heart health.

Name: Tietze Syndrome
Symptoms: Chest pain, swelling and tenderness of the cartilage connecting the ribs to the breastbone
Treatment: Treatment for Tietze Syndrome focuses on relieving pain and inflammation. Options may include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), pain relievers (such as acetaminophen), corticosteroid injections, physical therapy, and applying ice or heat packs to the affected area. Rest and avoiding activities that worsen symptoms may also be helpful. In severe cases, surgery to remove the affected cartilage may be considered.

Name: Cranial Nerve Palsy
Symptoms: Depends on the specific cranial nerve involved; symptoms can include vision changes, eye movement abnormalities, facial weakness or paralysis, difficulty swallowing or speaking, loss of sensation in the face or other areas
Treatment: Treatment for Cranial Nerve Palsy depends on the underlying cause and specific symptoms. Options may include medications to manage pain or inflammation, physical therapy to improve muscle strength and coordination, speech therapy to address swallowing or speech difficulties, and surgery to decompress or repair the affected nerve. In some cases, symptoms may improve or resolve over time without specific treatment.

Name: Conversion Disorder
Symptoms: Neurological symptoms that cannot be explained by a medical condition or injury, such as paralysis, blindness, seizures, or difficulty speaking
Treatment: Treatment for Conversion Disorder often involves a multidisciplinary approach, including psychotherapy, physical therapy, and medications to manage symptoms such as depression or anxiety. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) may be helpful in addressing underlying psychological factors contributing to symptoms. Supportive therapy, education, and reassurance from healthcare providers are also important components of treatment.

Name: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome
Symptoms: Severe and chronic pain, often in the limbs, with associated swelling, changes in skin color or temperature, abnormal sweating, limited range of motion
Treatment: Treatment for Complex Regional Pain Syndrome aims to relieve pain, improve function, and restore quality of life. Options may include physical therapy, occupational therapy, medications (such as pain relievers, antidepressants, anticonvulsants, or topical agents), nerve blocks, spinal cord stimulation, and alternative therapies (such as biofeedback, acupuncture, or mirror therapy). Multidisciplinary pain management programs may offer comprehensive treatment approaches tailored to individual needs.

Name: Otosclerosis
Symptoms: Hearing loss (gradual and progressive), tinnitus (ringing in the ears), dizziness or balance problems
Treatment: Treatment for Otosclerosis may include hearing aids to improve communication and quality of life, especially in the early stages of the disease. Surgical interventions such as stapedectomy or stapedotomy may be considered to restore hearing in cases of significant hearing loss or when hearing aids are not sufficient. Counseling and education about coping strategies and communication techniques may also be beneficial.

Name: Hypothyroidism
Symptoms: Fatigue, weight gain, sensitivity to cold, dry skin, constipation, depression, muscle weakness, elevated cholesterol levels
Treatment: Treatment for Hypothyroidism typically involves lifelong thyroid hormone replacement therapy to restore hormone levels to normal. Options may include levothyroxine (Synthroid, Levoxyl, Tirosint) or other thyroid hormone medications. The dosage is adjusted based on individual factors such as age, weight, and underlying health conditions. Regular monitoring of thyroid function and adjustments to medication dosage are necessary to maintain optimal thyroid hormone levels and manage symptoms effectively.

Name: Primary Insomnia
Symptoms: Difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep, daytime sleepiness, irritability, difficulty concentrating
Treatment: Treatment for Primary Insomnia focuses on improving sleep quality and duration, as well as addressing underlying factors contributing to sleep disturbances. Options may include cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I), sleep hygiene education, relaxation techniques, and lifestyle modifications (such as establishing a consistent sleep schedule, limiting caffeine and alcohol intake, and creating a comfortable sleep environment). Medications such as sedative-hypnotics may be prescribed for short-term use in certain situations, but long-term use is generally not recommended due to the risk of tolerance, dependence, and side effects.

Name: Lice
Symptoms: Itching and visible presence of lice or nits (eggs) in the hair
Treatment: Treatment for Lice typically involves using over-the-counter or prescription medications to kill lice and their eggs (nits). Options may include pediculicides (such as permethrin or pyrethrin), which are applied to the scalp and hair according to package instructions. Combing the hair with a fine-toothed comb to remove dead lice and nits may also be recommended. It's important to follow treatment instructions carefully and to repeat treatment as needed to ensure complete eradication of lice and prevent reinfestation.

Name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
Symptoms: Fatigue, weakness, pale skin, shortness of breath, tingling or numbness in the hands and feet, balance problems, sore tongue
Treatment: Treatment for Vitamin B12 Deficiency typically involves vitamin B12 supplementation to restore normal levels in the body. Options may include oral vitamin B12 supplements (such as cyanocobalamin or methylcobalamin), intramuscular injections of vitamin B12, or high-dose oral supplements for individuals with malabsorption issues. In addition to supplementation, addressing underlying causes of vitamin B12 deficiency (such as pernicious anemia or dietary deficiencies) may be necessary for long-term management.

Name: Vulvodynia
Symptoms: Persistent pain or discomfort in the vulva, burning, stinging, rawness, itching
Treatment: Treatment for Vulvodynia aims to relieve symptoms and improve quality of life. Options may include topical medications (such as lidocaine or estrogen cream), oral medications (such as tricyclic antidepressants or anticonvulsants), physical therapy (including pelvic floor muscle relaxation techniques), biofeedback, nerve blocks, dietary modifications, and lifestyle changes (such as wearing cotton underwear and avoiding irritants). Individualized treatment plans may be developed based on the underlying cause of vulvodynia and the specific needs of the patient.

Name: Endometriosis
Symptoms: Pelvic pain (during menstruation, intercourse, or bowel movements), heavy menstrual bleeding, infertility
Treatment: Treatment for Endometriosis depends on the severity of symptoms, the extent of the disease, and the patient's reproductive goals. Options may include pain management with over-the-counter or prescription medications (such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs or hormonal contraceptives), hormone therapy (such as gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists or progestins), surgical interventions (such as laparoscopy or laparotomy to remove endometrial implants or adhesions), and fertility treatments for individuals experiencing infertility. Lifestyle modifications and complementary therapies may also be recommended to manage symptoms and improve quality of life.

Name: Vasculitis
Symptoms: Inflammation of blood vessels leading to various symptoms depending on the affected organs, including rash, fever, fatigue, muscle and joint pain, shortness of breath, weight loss
Treatment: Treatment for Vasculitis aims to reduce inflammation, control symptoms, and prevent complications such as organ damage or flare-ups. Options may include corticosteroids (such as prednisone), immunosuppressive medications (such as cyclophosphamide or methotrexate), biologic agents (such as rituximab or tocilizumab), and other immunomodulatory therapies. The choice of treatment depends on the type and severity of vasculitis, as well as individual factors such as age, overall health, and medication tolerability. Close monitoring and regular follow-up with healthcare providers are important to assess treatment response and adjust therapy as needed.

Name: Concussion
Symptoms: Headache, dizziness, nausea or vomiting, confusion, memory problems, sensitivity to light or noise, mood changes
Treatment: Treatment for Concussion typically involves rest and gradual return to activity under the guidance of a healthcare provider. Options may include physical and cognitive rest in the acute phase of injury, followed by a gradual increase in activity level based on symptoms. Medications such as pain relievers (such as acetaminophen) may be used to manage headache or other symptoms. Cognitive rehabilitation, vestibular therapy, and other rehabilitation interventions may be recommended for persistent or disabling symptoms. Close monitoring and follow-up with a healthcare provider are important to ensure proper management and recovery.

Name: Oral Leukoplakia
Symptoms: White patches or plaques in the mouth, often on the tongue or inside of the cheeks, that cannot be scraped off
Treatment: Treatment for Oral Leukoplakia aims to remove or manage the precancerous lesions and reduce the risk of progression to oral cancer. Options may include cessation of tobacco use (if applicable), removal of irritants or sources of trauma, topical medications (such as retinoids or corticosteroids), cryotherapy (freezing the lesions with liquid nitrogen), laser therapy, or surgical excision. Regular monitoring and follow-up with a dentist or oral surgeon are important to monitor for changes in the lesions and assess treatment response.

Name: Chronic Kidney Disease
Symptoms: Fatigue, swelling of the legs or ankles, decreased appetite, difficulty concentrating, increased urination or urine changes, blood in urine, high blood pressure
Treatment: Treatment for Chronic Kidney Disease focuses on managing symptoms, slowing disease progression, and reducing the risk of complications such as cardiovascular disease and kidney failure. Options may include lifestyle modifications (such as dietary changes, smoking cessation, and regular exercise), medications to control blood pressure and manage symptoms (such as diuretics, ACE inhibitors, or phosphate binders), and treatment of underlying conditions contributing to kidney damage. In advanced stages of kidney disease, dialysis or kidney transplantation may be necessary.

Name: Bladder Disorder
Symptoms: Frequent urination, urgency, pelvic pain
Treatment: Treatment for Bladder Disorder depends on the underlying cause and specific symptoms. Options may include lifestyle modifications (such as bladder training, fluid management, and pelvic floor exercises), medications to reduce urinary frequency and urgency (such as anticholinergics or beta-3 agonists), bladder instillations or injections to relieve pain or inflammation, neuromodulation therapies (such as sacral nerve stimulation), and surgical interventions (such as bladder augmentation or urinary diversion) for severe cases or refractory symptoms. Individualized treatment plans may be developed based on the patient's medical history, symptom severity, and treatment goals.

Name: Chorioretinitis
Symptoms: Eye pain, blurred vision, sensitivity to light
Treatment: Treatment for Chorioretinitis aims to eliminate the underlying cause of inflammation and prevent vision loss or complications such as retinal detachment or macular edema. Options may include antimicrobial medications (such as antibiotics, antivirals, or antifungals) to treat infectious causes of chorioretinitis, corticosteroids to reduce inflammation, and immunosuppressive agents in cases of autoimmune or inflammatory chorioretinitis. Close monitoring and follow-up with an ophthalmologist are important to assess treatment response and monitor for recurrence or progression of the condition.

Name: Priapism
Symptoms: Persistent, painful erection
Treatment: Treatment for Priapism depends on the type (ischemic or nonischemic), duration, and underlying cause of the prolonged erection. Options may include conservative measures such as ice packs, pain relief medications, oral or injectable sympathomimetics (such as pseudoephedrine or phenylephrine) to promote penile detumescence, aspiration or drainage of blood from the penis, and intracavernosal injection of vasoconstrictive agents (such as phenylephrine) under medical supervision. In severe or refractory cases, surgical interventions such as shunts or penile prosthesis placement may be necessary to relieve priapism and prevent complications such as erectile dysfunction.

Name: Myositis
Symptoms: Muscle weakness, pain, inflammation
Treatment: Treatment for Myositis aims to reduce inflammation, relieve symptoms, and improve muscle function and quality of life. Options may include corticosteroids (such as prednisone) to suppress inflammation, immunosuppressive medications (such as azathioprine or methotrexate) for refractory cases or to reduce steroid dosage, physical therapy to improve muscle strength, flexibility, and endurance, and lifestyle modifications (such as rest, exercise, and dietary changes) to manage symptoms and maintain overall health. In some cases, intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) or biologic agents may be used for severe or rapidly progressive myositis.

Name: Mononucleosis
Symptoms: Fatigue, sore throat, swollen lymph nodes
Treatment: Treatment for Mononucleosis focuses on relieving symptoms and preventing complications. Options may include rest, hydration, and over-the-counter pain relievers (such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen) to reduce fever and relieve discomfort. Corticosteroids may be prescribed in certain situations to reduce inflammation and swelling of the throat or tonsils. Antibiotics are not effective against viral infections like mononucleosis and are not routinely recommended unless there is a bacterial complication (such as streptococcal pharyngitis). It's important to avoid contact sports and other strenuous activities until cleared by a healthcare provider to prevent complications such as splenic rupture.

Name: Neuralgia
Symptoms: Sharp, shooting pain along the affected nerve
Treatment: Treatment for Neuralgia aims to relieve pain, improve function, and enhance quality of life. Options may include medications (such as anticonvulsants, tricyclic antidepressants, or topical agents) to modulate pain signals and reduce nerve sensitivity, nerve blocks or injections (such as corticosteroids or local anesthetics) to block pain signals and provide temporary relief, physical therapy to improve muscle strength, flexibility, and posture, and complementary therapies (such as acupuncture, biofeedback, or relaxation techniques) to manage pain and stress. In some cases, surgical interventions such as nerve decompression or neuromodulation may be considered for refractory neuralgia.

Name: Polycystic Kidney Disease
Symptoms: Abdominal pain, high blood pressure, kidney cysts
Treatment: Treatment for Polycystic Kidney Disease focuses on managing symptoms, preventing complications, and slowing disease progression. Options may include lifestyle modifications (such as dietary changes, exercise, and smoking cessation), medications to control blood pressure and manage symptoms (such as pain relievers or antibiotics for cyst infections), and surveillance for complications such as hypertension, kidney stones, cyst hemorrhage, or kidney failure. In advanced stages of the disease, renal replacement therapy such as dialysis or kidney transplantation may be necessary.

Name: Bipolar Disorder
Symptoms: Mood swings, manic episodes, depressive episodes
Treatment: Treatment for Bipolar Disorder typically involves a combination of medication, psychotherapy, and lifestyle adjustments to manage mood symptoms, prevent relapses, and improve overall functioning. Options may include mood stabilizers (such as lithium, valproate, or lamotrigine), atypical antipsychotics, antidepressants, or other medications to manage specific symptoms or phases of the illness. Psychotherapy approaches such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), interpersonal and social rhythm therapy (IPSRT), or family-focused therapy may be beneficial in addressing mood regulation, stress management, and interpersonal relationships. Lifestyle modifications such as maintaining a regular sleep schedule, avoiding alcohol and recreational drugs, and engaging in regular exercise and social activities may also support mood stability and recovery.

Name: Amyloidosis
Symptoms: Fatigue, weight loss, organ dysfunction
Treatment: Treatment for Amyloidosis aims to reduce amyloid protein production, prevent organ damage, and manage symptoms to improve quality of life. Options may include chemotherapy, targeted therapy (such as proteasome inhibitors or monoclonal antibodies), stem cell transplantation, and supportive therapies (such as diuretics, antiarrhythmics, or anticoagulants) to manage complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, or clotting disorders. Close monitoring and follow-up with healthcare providers are important to assess treatment response, monitor for disease progression, and manage side effects of therapy.

Name: Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP)
Symptoms: Weakness, numbness, tingling in limbs
Treatment: Treatment for Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP) aims to reduce inflammation, improve nerve function, and relieve symptoms. Options may include corticosteroids (such as prednisone), intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) infusions, plasma exchange (plasmapheresis), immunosuppressive medications (such as azathioprine or mycophenolate), and monoclonal antibodies (such as rituximab) to modulate the immune response. Physical therapy, occupational therapy, and assistive devices may also be recommended to improve mobility, strength, and function. Close monitoring and regular follow-up with a neurologist are important to assess treatment response and adjust therapy as needed.

Name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
Symptoms: Heartburn, acid reflux, chest pain
Treatment: Treatment for Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) aims to reduce acid production, relieve symptoms, and prevent complications such as esophagitis or Barrett's esophagus. Options may include lifestyle modifications (such as dietary changes, weight loss, and elevation of the head of the bed), over-the-counter or prescription medications to reduce acid production (such as proton pump inhibitors, H2-receptor antagonists, or antacids), and surgery (such as fundoplication) for severe or refractory cases. Avoiding trigger foods and beverages, eating smaller meals, and avoiding lying down after eating may also help manage symptoms and improve quality of life.

Name: Vitreous Hemorrhage
Symptoms: Floaters in vision, blurry vision, eye pain
Treatment: Treatment for Vitreous Hemorrhage depends on the underlying cause and severity of symptoms. Options may include observation and monitoring for spontaneous resolution, medications to manage complications such as inflammation or elevated intraocular pressure, laser therapy or cryotherapy to seal leaking blood vessels, and vitrectomy surgery to remove blood and debris from the vitreous cavity in cases of severe or persistent hemorrhage. Close monitoring and follow-up with an ophthalmologist are important to assess treatment response and prevent complications such as retinal detachment or vision loss.

Name: Antimicrobial Drugs Poisoning
Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, neurological symptoms
Treatment: Treatment for Antimicrobial Drugs Poisoning depends on the specific drug involved, route of exposure, and severity of symptoms. Options may include supportive care (such as intravenous fluids, electrolyte replacement, and antiemetics to manage nausea and vomiting), activated charcoal or gastric lavage to prevent absorption of the toxin, and administration of antidotes or specific therapies for certain types of poisoning (such as naloxone for opioid overdose or chelation therapy for heavy metal poisoning). Close monitoring and supportive interventions are essential to prevent complications and facilitate recovery.

Name: Scleroderma
Symptoms: Thickening of the skin, Raynaud's phenomenon
Treatment: Treatment for Scleroderma aims to manage symptoms, prevent complications, and improve quality of life. Options may include medications to manage symptoms such as pain, heartburn, or Raynaud's phenomenon (such as calcium channel blockers, proton pump inhibitors, or vasodilators), immunosuppressive medications to reduce inflammation and slow disease progression (such as corticosteroids, methotrexate, or mycophenolate), and targeted therapies to address specific complications or organ involvement (such as endothelin receptor antagonists or phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitors for pulmonary hypertension). Physical therapy, occupational therapy, and lifestyle modifications may also be recommended to maintain mobility, function, and overall well-being.

Name: Myasthenia Gravis
Symptoms: Muscle weakness, fatigue, difficulty speaking
